headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Biden At White House BBQ: "I'm Not Going Anywhere"; Labour Party Wins UK Election In Landslide; Hurricane Beryl Weakens To Category 2 On Path To Mexico. Aired 5-5:30a ET

utterances.speaker: PAULA REID, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: It is Friday, July 5th.Right now on CNN THIS MORNING: Joe Biden and the political fight of his life. His plan for proving he's fit for office? Getting more sleep. Plus -- (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KEIR STARMER, UK LABOUR PARTY LEADER
utterances.sentences: We did it!(CHEERS)

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: A landslide win in the UK, power shifting to the Labour Party for the first time in over a decade.And this -- Hurricane Beryl tearing up the Caribbean, now heading towards Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. (MUSIC)

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: Five a.m. here in Washington. Here's a live look at Capitol Hill.Good morning, everyone. I'm Paula Reid, in for Kasie Hunt. It's great to be with you. More sleep, less work. That's President Biden's plan to stay sharp and focused on the job after last week's devastating debate performance. According to three sources, the president intends to stop scheduling events after 8:00 p.m. so he can get more rest. And there's no sign he's considering bowing out of the race. Listen to these remarks at yesterday's July 4th barbecue at the White House. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: This could not be done without the family support, so thank you. Thank you. Thank you. We love you and I really needed from the bottom of my heart. Thank you. Thank you.You got me, man. I'm not going anywhere. All right. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: To stay in the race, President Biden has to calm fears among his own supporters about his mental fitness. He didn't help his cause in this interview with the Philadelphia radio show.(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I'm proud to be, as I said, the first vice president -- first Black woman -- to serve with a Black president, proud to have been involved with the first Black woman on the Supreme Court.(END AUDIO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: Let's bring in, Mariana Alfaro, national politics and breaking news reporter for "The Washington Post".Thank you for being up early with us. Let's start with the big question everyone has. I mean, is it even possible that Biden would step aside right now?

utterances.speaker: MARIANA ALFARO, NATIONAL POLITICS BREAKING NEWS REPORTER, THE WASHINGTON POST
utterances.sentences: Well, coming from all the conversations we've been having, you know, hearing from governors after this meeting, they had. I want to say it seems like he has very -- sure that he won't step out and I think that right now again, we haven't seen a lot of pressure from other elected Democrats, especially in Congress, because they've been out this week.But I think that this coming week when they returned to the Hill, we'll be hearing to see if more come out and call him from for it, but after this governors' meeting, it's pretty evident that he has no desire to step down and he ultimately, we've heard from so many Democrats, that he is still want to make the call. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: So what are you hearing from sources right now about the conversations inside the White House?

utterances.speaker: ALFARO
utterances.sentences: Yeah. So I mean, specifically from this governors' reunion, I think we came out hearing a lot of these governor, Democrat governors saying that they still have the confidence in Biden, they still -- you know, that he has to make the choice, but also you heard I think it was a New Mexico governor, Maine governor saying, were not sure if you can win or state in the state.I think we need to be reassured more and I think that that's the kind of conflict that Democrats are hearing right out across the country. They want to continue supporting Biden, but also they know that it could hurt on not only him, but the rest of the party already on the ticket come November.

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: And what do you expect over the next few days? ALFAROTuesday, I think we're going to be hearing a lot of Democrats, maybe be more open, be more candid about what's going on. But I think that there's still a lot of confusion within the caucus in the Senate groups and they are still waiting to see their leadership act more strongly. I think that were trying to get them on the Hill next week and see what their thoughts are. But I do expect the list of House Democrats calling him to leave the ticket to micro in the coming week.

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: And just say you think it'll grow. And what is the conversation around the other option? What is the other option? Obviously, he has a vice president, but there's a list of names. What are you hearing?

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: You mentioned campaign funds because there are consequences to who use decide to select someone else, money can follow some of them, but not everyone -- the money that Biden has in his war chest.

utterances.speaker: ALFARO
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think how it works is that if he were to step down or leave the ticket because Harris is already part of the campaign, it would be easier to transfer to her. But if not, if it was a new candidate, it raises a new -- new sort of questions that we've never seen before about where do we start with fundraising? Where do we start with gathering all of the Democratic war chest behind him or her?And I think that right now. Those are a lot of things that we've never been put institution, we never been put in before. So I think for a lot of strategists, a lot of people trying to see, first of all, Kamala Harris might be the more clear, easy cut path because again, they're running out of time.

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: Yeah. No, I think how often have we said that over the past eight or nine years, a place we've never been before.Based on your reporting, how important is the next 24, 48 hours with this ABC News interview tonight. I think that whatever happens tonight, and also, I guess were going to see the big parts come out tonight and I think Sunday might be a bit more of the relaxed parts of the interview, but I think President Biden has this one shot that everyone has been calling for it to have a clear communication with work journalist to be open and candid and have any question thrown at him. And I think that really depends on how that goes. Its really going to set up the situation for House Democratic, Senate Democrats coming up next week in the White House is responsible. Again, the campaign has been keeping the same talking points, you know, say he was tired, he was traveling a lot. You know, there's no excuse behind that for a sit-down interview with a journalist. So we'll see how it goes in the new spin be after that.

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, it'll be high-stakes.

utterances.speaker: ALFARO
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's very high stakes.

utterances.speaker: STARMER
utterances.sentences: We did it! You campaign for it. You fought for it. You voted for it. And now, it has arrived. Change begins now.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: For the first time in over a decade, the conservative party in Britain is out and the Labour Party is in.Overnight, conservative British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak conceded the election, promising a peaceful transfer of power. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RISHI SUNAK, CONSERVATIVE BRITISH PRIME MNISTER
utterances.sentences: The Labour Party has won this general election. And I've called to Keir Starmer to congratulate him on his victory. Today, power will change hands in a peaceful and orderly manner, with goodwill on all sides.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: The landslide victory for Labour gives them control of the British government for the first time in 14 years, with Labour leader Keir Starmer now taking reins as the next prime minister.So let's bring in CNN's Max Foster to break all of this down with us. Max, things are moving very quickly this morning. Tell us about the process to move from one prime minister to another. MAX FOSTER, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR & CORRESPONDENT:  So we're about to see Rishi Sunak move out of Downing Street. He'll head up to the palace. He'll resign. The palace in front of the king and then Keir Starmer will come in and be appointed and then hell move into Downing Street. There'll be speeches on both sides. There is this unique thing, though, Paula, well, for that moment between the resignation and the appointment, the king is running the country. So an absolute monarchy for about ten minutes, probably. But I think what we've seen here is in some ways, isn't a massive shift. You still got a center ground prime minister, but it's moved to the left slightly, and by a landslide. So the British public have completely flipped in many of their voting patterns, even in Scotland, with the Scottish national party has seen its vote collapse. There's been a lot of change here and a triumph for Keir Starmer, because the last election, the Labour Party had the worst showing that its ever had now its got one of its best showings. But you have underneath all of that something very interesting going on. You're seeing the hard and the hard left also having successes. So, the Green Party getting four seats, whereas is extraordinary, Nigel Farage, who was honestly very close to Donald Trump, winning a seat. But also he got the conservatives collapsing. You're going to see the hard right having an influence on the new conservative party that comes out of this. So, it's not to say the hard-right haven't had a role to play here in the same way they have in other parts of Europe. It's just not as defined, but we have got now a centrist government which has moved slightly to the left.

utterances.speaker: FOSTER
utterances.sentences: He's a former human rights lawyer. He is a Blairite, very similar to Tony Blair. He's also taken on some pretty right-wing policies like stopping the boats of immigrants, illegal immigrants coming into the UK. He's made massive promises about what he can afford to do, such as bringing public services back to what they used to be none of which is affordable.So this isn't the same as Tony Blair in 1997 coming off a huge wave of optimism, and celebration. This is Keir Starmer saying people have voted for change is pretty much against the conservative party. And what people used to have. And he's going to change things, but it's very difficult to see how he's going to be able to afford it, and he doesn't -- if you actually look at the votes, he didn't have that many votes across the nation, but he did very cleverly worked through the system, the first past, the post system, which is what we've got constitutionally here, which allowed him tactically to win. This is not a resounding win for him, although he's got a lot more power in parliament to do what he wants to do.

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: And, Max, we just got some new reporting that 40 percent of voters skip the election. What does that say to you?

utterances.speaker: FOSTER
utterances.sentences: Well, slightly down from last time, but if you look at the trend, it's an absolute collapse in the number of people voting. The turnout has been absolutely terrible. What it says to me is people weren't engaged in this election. You might say, well, they've been so many elections here and we had the Brexit referendum, so many prime ministers, people are just tuned out.I do worry that this is a crushing defeat, not just for the conservative party, but for politics. Politics isn't changing things in the same way that people hoped. So they're just not engaging in it. And I think that's pretty depressing. And it says a lot about democracy. And people losing faith in it, frankly.

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: This morning, Hurricane Beryl is bearing down on Mexico, weakening slightly overnight to a strong category two hurricane. The storm just battered Jamaica with strong winds and a months worth of rain in just 24 hours.CNN's Rafael Romo reports on the damage from Kingston. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) RAFAEL ROMO, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  Winds and rain pummel Jamaica for 12 hours. Beryl is the strongest hurricane to strike the island in more than 15 years, tearing a path of destruction through the Eastern Caribbean. Now, the cleanup begins.

utterances.speaker: DICKON MITCHEL, PRIME MINISTER OF GRENADA
utterances.sentences: To see this level of destruction, it is almost Armageddon-like, almost total damage or destruction of all buildings.

utterances.speaker: ROMO
utterances.sentences: Many people living on these small islands lost everything.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's just unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Everything is gone. Everything you can think about is gone. People are homeless. They need food. They need water.

utterances.speaker: ROMO
utterances.sentences: The eye of the storm passed less than 20 miles south of Jamaica, which seems to have pulled out of this major hurricane better than expected.

utterances.speaker: ANDREW HOLNESS, PRIME MINISTER OF JAMAICA
utterances.sentences: I think Jamaica was spared the worst. The damage was not what we had expected, and so were very grateful for that.

utterances.speaker: ROMO
utterances.sentences: Many residents we spoke with agree.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The greatest thing is we have life, we're still here. That's the greatest thing.

utterances.speaker: ROMO
utterances.sentences: This fishing village, just outside Kingston, is one of the hardest hit communities in the area. Take a look at how the powerful hurricane winds destroyed their sheds and stands that they depend for their livelihoods. Now they wonder how long its going to take before they can rebuild.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's going to be expensive to rebuild back everything, but in time, it will be done.

utterances.speaker: ROMO
utterances.sentences: The shop owners guided us through the debris-filled beach front.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: One shed here, another there and that's a (INAUDIBLE). Rooftop blew off, the (INAUDIBLE) also blew off.

utterances.speaker: ROMO
utterances.sentences: The deluge from Beryl triggering flooding and forcing around the thousand people into shelters. The storm dumped more than twice the average July rainfall on the city of Kingston in just 24 hours. Never before has the Caribbean been battered by a hurricane this strong, this early in the year.(END VIDEOTAPE) ROMO (on camera):  Here in Jamaica, Prime Minister Andrew Holness earlier said that about 1,000 people remain in shelters. As for communications, he also said that 70 percent of the network was operational. Power also went out in some areas about he said that it was being restored already. Rafael Romo, CNN, Kingston, Jamaica.

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: Beryl is now bearing down on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. And this morning, Mexico's president is urging residents of Tulum to seek shelter.Let's get right to meteorologist Elisa Raffa. Elisa, where is the storm right now?
